Comment: A great book that goes into this is *Why Nations Fail* by Acemoglu and Robinson. I think they would contend that any country with a huge population and pre-industrial economy could see a great deal of rapid economic growth just by industrializing, but the tricky part is turning that into sustainable, long term economic growth once that country is "caught up." The example here being the USSR that showed incredible economic growth in the post-war period only to hit a plateau because they didn't create sufficiently inclusive economic and political structures.  When the book was published, China had seen similar early growth, only to taper off a bit, but not as much as in the USSR because China did some economic reform that moved towards more inclusive structures (though it was an open question how much that could continue without continuing to more economic inclusivity).   I see no reason why India would be any different. India could easily be the next country to have that kind of economic growth (assuming the political system changes enough to allow that--both USSR and China's growth came only after socialist revolutions). But whether that growth could continue after they are "caught up" is the much harder question.  *Why Nations Fail* isn't without its detractors, though, so it's very possible that they're completely wrong about this. I mean, India hasn't seen that transformation yet despite seeming being ripe for it, so maybe not.  As far as Russia, I think with the invasion of Ukraine struggling so, you could make the argument that Russia is *already* a second-rate power.
